title: Kansas County Pays for Police Raid on Newspaper
summary: In Kansas, Marion County has agreed to pay $3 million and say sorry for a police raid on a newspaper in 2023. This means the county admits it was wrong to send police to search the newspaper's office. At the same time, other news includes the Justice Department looking into safety at UC Berkeley after protests led to arrests, and a judge in Utah changing the voting map to help Democrats win more votes. These events show how the government and police must follow rules to protect people's rights, like the freedom of the press.

background_read: This article talks about events in the United States where the government is taking steps to fix mistakes or improve safety. In Kansas, a county is paying money and apologizing because police raided a newspaper, which might have broken the law protecting free speech. In California, the Justice Department is checking security at a university after protests to ensure everyone is safe. In Utah, a judge changed how voting areas are drawn to make elections fairer. These stories show how laws and rules help keep people safe and protect their rights.
